intro: Anthocercis odgersii, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Asparagaceae and is characterized by its strap-shaped leaves that are used for weaving traditional Māori garments. The plant produces small, white flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, which are typically found at the base of the leaves. It thrives in coastal and wetland environments, preferring moist, well-drained soils. Due to its historical and cultural significance, it is also valued for its ecological role in supporting native wildlife.
